title: Second Council of Constantinople
description: The Fifth Ecumenical Council, which reaffirmed Chalcedon and condemned key Nestorian formulations (553).

content.text: Convened in Constantinople under Emperor Justinian I, this council sought to preserve the teaching of Chalcedon while addressing ongoing Christological disputes in the eastern churches.

items: Reaffirmed the faith of Nicaea (325), Constantinople (381), Ephesus (431), and Chalcedon (451).
Condemned the so-called 'Three Chapters' associated with Theodore of Mopsuestia, certain writings of Theodoret of Cyrus, and the letter of Ibas of Edessa.
Reasserted that the eternal Word is one person (hypostasis) incarnate, guarding against dividing Christ into two persons.
Upheld the title Theotokos ('God-bearer') for the Virgin Mary as a Christological confession about the person of Christ.

content.text: The council presented itself as continuous with Chalcedon, not a rejection of it. Its canons aimed to secure orthodox Christology by clarifying how Christ's divine and human realities are united in one person.
